title: Poręba
text:
Poręba is a town in <a href="Zawiercie%20County">Zawiercie County</a>, <a href="Silesian%20Voivodeship">Silesian Voivodeship</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, with 8,525 inhabitants (2019). The town has the area of , and lies along National Road Nr. 78; it also has a rail station on a line from <a href="Miasteczko%20%C5%9Al%C4%85skie">Miasteczko Śląskie</a> to <a href="Zawiercie">Zawiercie</a>. Almost half of Poręba's area (49%) is covered by forests.
History.
Poręba belongs to <a href="Lesser%20Poland">Lesser Poland</a>, and until 1795 (see <a href="Partitions%20of%20Poland">Partitions of Poland</a>), it was part of the <a href="Krak%C3%B3w%20Voivodeship%20%2814th%20century%20%E2%80%93%201795%29">Kraków Voivodeship</a> of the <a href="Lesser%20Poland%20Province%20of%20the%20Polish%20Crown">Lesser Poland Province of the Polish Crown</a>. First mention of the Poręba settlement comes from 1375, and at that time, it was called Black Poręba, located by a lake called Black Lake. Until the 16th century, the area was sparsely populated, and covered by dense woods. The development of industry resulted in influx of settlers, and in the 16th century Poręba became a center of early steel and iron plants. The village belonged at that time to the Pilecki family. In 1795, after the <a href="Third%20Partition%20of%20Poland">Third Partition of Poland</a>, it was annexed by <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Prussia</a>. The first <a href="blast%20furnace">blast furnace</a> was built in 1798 by efforts of Count . In 1806 the village was regained by Poles, and included within the short-lived Polish <a href="Duchy%20of%20Warsaw">Duchy of Warsaw</a>, and in 1815, it became part of <a href="Russian%20Partition">Russian</a>-controlled <a href="Congress%20Poland">Congress Poland</a>, and Poręba further developed, becoming a local industrial center.
In 1918 Poręba returned to the re-created Poland, and in the <a href="Second%20Polish%20Republic">Second Polish Republic</a>, the settlement belonged to <a href="Kielce%20Voivodeship">Kielce Voivodeship</a>. During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Poręba was <a href="Occupation%20of%20Poland%20%281939%E2%80%931945%29">occupied by Germany</a> from 1939 to 1945. Poręba developed further in the 1950s, when local metal plant began manufacturing <a href="machine%20tool">machine tool</a>s. A <a href="vocational%20school">vocational school</a> was opened in 1946, which in the late 1960s moved into a new complex. Furthermore, in the 1960s, a recreational center for local workers was built. In 1975–1982, Poręba was a district of Zawiercie.
In 2008, <a href="Triassic">Triassic</a> turtle remains were discovered in the area.
Sports.
The local <a href="Association%20football">football</a> club is MKS Poręba. It competes in the lower leagues.
Cuisine.
<a href="Pra%C5%BConki">Prażonki</a> is a traditional regional dish originating from Poręba. It is prepared from <a href="potato">potato</a>es, <a href="onion">onion</a>s, <a href="kie%C5%82basa">kiełbasa</a>, <a href="bacon">bacon</a>, <a href="lard">lard</a>, <a href="salt">salt</a>, pepper and <a href="cabbage">cabbage</a>. Other officially protected <a href="traditional%20food">traditional food</a>s from Poręba are "kiełbasa porębska", a local type of kiełbasa, and "szynka wieprzowa parzona porębska", a local type of <a href="Steaming">steamed</a> <a href="ham">ham</a> (as designated by the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Agriculture%20and%20Rural%20Development%20%28Poland%29">Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development of Poland</a>).
